Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X5Y-5111-JB20-G4B7-00000-00State Secretary Mike Pompeo Answers Questions in Italy; Interview with Rep. Mark Green (R) Tennessee2019-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:53ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTRep. Mark Green, Don Peebles, Andy Puzder, Thomas Barkin, Cathy EngelbertNEWSDomestic100202cb.231State Secretary Mike Pompeo Answers Questions in Italy; Interview with Rep. Mark Green (R) TennesseeMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Jackie DeAngelis, Edward Lawrence

UNIDENTIFIED MALE (through translator): We'll begin with the Italian journalist, Francesco Sforza (ph) of Stampa.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Minister Di Maio and Secretary Pompeo -- as far as the Berlin conference in Libya is concerned and given the violence by General Haftar's troops over the past few hours and days, how does the U.S. intend to support Italy's approach when it comes to ending the violence and to promote a cease fire? With which interlocutors do you intend to work with and how?

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: We had extensive discussions today, we had them with President Mattarella and Prime Minister Conte as well about Libya. Our mission set is very similar. We recognize that the first and most important thing we need to do is take down the level of violence, achieve a cease fire to convince all the relevant parties that are on the ground there's as well as those that have been supporting from the outside that a political solution is the only one that provides any real opportunity to create an outcome in Libya that is remotely adequate for Italy. But most importantly, for the people of Libya as well.

So our mission set alongside our Italian partners is to convince all of the relevant parties that the political process must move forward. And I'm hopeful that whether it's the Berlin conference or some of the other work that's going to take place over the coming weeks, that we can achieve that outcome.

LUIGI DI MAIO, ITALIAN FOREIGN MINISTER (through translator): This topic was obviously one which was discussed during all the talks we had last week in New York during the U.N.G.A. And we agree on the principle that in order for there to be a cease fire, there should be no countries which stimulate this conflict on the one side and on the other.

And the moral suasion that a country like Italy can have is very important on some of the players involved in the conflict, be they Libyan players or non-Libyan players. But of course the role, the moral suasion that a world power like the U.S. can exercise is just as important.

And we believe that the Berlin conference, if prepared adequately, and by involving the players in the conflict as much as possible, we feel that this can lead to a further step forward. Of course, the step forward has to lead to a cease fire and has to lead towards a political process that can lead to the stabilization of Libya.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Vincenzo Nigro -- La Republicca.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Good morning. I'd like to ask both of you to discuss the Iran issue in greater detail. Secretary Pompeo -- do you think that returning to negotiation, be it a direct or indirect negotiation, we all read about the alleged phone call between President Trump and President Rouhani at the U.N.

But does the Department of State favor a renewal in talks? And is it willing to reduce this maximum sanctions policy against Iran.

And I'd also like to ask Mr. Di Maio -- in your introductory speech you said that Italy continues to prefer a diplomatic and political discussion to the most serious crisis in the world and as far as the Mediterranean is concerned, of course, the most serious crisis is the Iranian one.

Secretary Pompeo also mentioned Mahan Air, an Iranian airline company. I didn't understand if Italy will be willing to sanction that airline too.

And one final remark, today I think marks the anniversary of the killing of the Saudi journalist, Mr. Khashoggi. Do you think that murder will have an influence on the way in which our governments looks towards the main players in the Middle Eastern region?

DI MAIO: Let me start answering by saying that it's obvious, it's clear that we agree on the fact --

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We are listening to the leadership there in Italy as well as Secretary of State Pompeo. We will get back to that as news develops.

So far, we heard the Secretary talk about Venezuela as well as Iran. No question so far about this impeachment inquiry. We'll get back to that as news develops there.

Want to bring in Tennessee Congressman and member of the Homeland Security and Oversight Committees, Mark Green. And Congressman -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for joining us.

REP. MARK GREEN (R-TN): Good to see you -- Maria. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to what you heard from Secretary Pompeo. And then we want to broaden out and ask you about the happenings in Washington.

GREEN: Sure. I really appreciate his stand with Iran and of course the issues in Libya. I think the Berlin conference is going to move us down the road there. What he didn't mention of course, North Korea launching the ballistic missile this morning. I'm sure that will come out -- hopefully it will come out. There will be a question on that.

And then the impeachment mess, I mean his comments recently have been very strong and I really appreciate his stand there.

BARTIROMO: So we've been talking about that this morning. And we want to get your take in terms of how this progresses --

GREEN: Sure.

BARTIROMO: Why there hasn't been an overall House vote to actually vote to launch the inquiry? And is this all about just putting on a show which is what Andrew McCarthy just said when he came on the show. The Democrats just putting on a show to try to delegitimize President Trump?

GREEN: Absolutely -- Maria. This is a travesty of democracy. I mean every single member of that House, the People's House represents 800,000 people. And when we vote, we're letting the voice of the American people be heard.

Yet the tyrannical leader of the House, the Speaker of the House is not letting us have a voice in this issue. She's just initiating this inquiry which really isn't official because we should have the opportunity to vote. The process is we vote and then committees go to work, forming articles of impeachment and doing their investigation.

We're not doing it that way because there are 31 Democrats sitting in seats that Trump won and they don't want to put those individuals on the hot seat. They're afraid they'll lose those seats, lose control of the House.

So she is going about this without letting the people have a voice or a say in it. And that is a threat to democracy. It is insane. It's crazy. I can't believe it's happening.

Leader McCarthy has tried multiple times to force a vote and they keep tabling it so that they don't have to vote. It's terrible. It's egregious. It should not be happening in America.

DON PEEBLES, CHAIRMAN, PEEBLES CORPORATION: Congressman -- Don Peebles.

GREEN: Hey -- Don.

PEEBLES: Good morning.

Doesn't Congress have more important things to do to move the country forward? Don't Americans have other very pressing issues right now? And are any of those things being addressed in this Congress?

GREEN: So I'll give you an example. I have a bill that would help rural hospitals. I think everybody knows I'm a physician. I'm a businessman --

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- stay with us for one moment. I'm sorry -- we want to get back to Italy because the Secretary --

GREEN: Sure.

BARTIROMO: -- just got a question on Ukraine. Let's hear his answer.

(LIVE EVENT)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: -- or the accounts that we've all seen of it including the transcript or partial transcript released by the White House accurate and complete. And if you were on the call did you hear anything on that in the conversation that raised a red flag, anything inappropriate or anything that gave you any concerns?

And then secondly, you told -- you said last week that you -- as far as you knew, everyone at the State Department has acted appropriately in regards to Ukraine and including yourself. And so is that still the case? Is that still your belief?

If it is, why object to the demand for deposition from the House committees on the hill? And then do you have any -- any concerns at all about what the State Department inspector general is going to be briefing to Hill staffers later today?

Thank you very much.

POMPEO: Thanks -- Matt. I'll try and answer questions four through seven first and then one through three after that.

Back to, first principles. The predicate of your final question about objecting to what the folks on Capitol Hill have asked is fundamentally not true.

What we objected to was the demands that were put that are deeply violating fundamental principles of separation of powers. They contacted State Department employees directly, told them not to contact legal counsel at the State Department. That's been reported to us.

They said that the State Department wouldn't be able to be present. There are important constitutional prerogatives that the executive branch has to be present so that we can protect the important information so our partners -- countries like Italy -- can have confidence that the information that they provide the State Department will continue to be protected.

And so the response that I provided to them was, one that acknowledge that we will of course do our constitutional duty to cooperate with this co- equal branch but we're going to do so in a way that is consistent with the fundamental values of the American system.

And we won't tolerate folks on Capitol Hill bullying, intimidating State Department employees. That's unacceptable and it's not something that I'm going to permit to happen.

As for was I on the phone call, the phone call was in the context of now I guess I've been Secretary of State for coming on a year-and-a-half. I know precisely what the American policy is with respect to Ukraine. It's been remarkably consistent and we will continue to try to drive those set of outcomes.

It's what our team including Ambassador Volker were focused on, was taking down the threat that Russia poses there in Ukraine. It was about helping the Ukrainians to get graft out and corruption outside of their government and to help now this new government in the Ukraine build a successful thriving economy.

It's what the State Department officials that I have had the privilege to lead have been engaged in and it's what we will continue to do even while all this noise is going on.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ok. Chris O'Day -- "National Review".

CHRIS O'DAY, "NATIONAL REVIEW": Thank you both for being here.

I'd like to I guess address the question to both of you. You can kind of take it in whichever order -- whoever wants to kind of go first.

Primarily oriented towards I guess what is conveniently termed kind of the belt-and-road these days. But on a somewhat broader basis, not just with Huawei, but does the U.S. have any specific plans in terms of how to counter China's investment in these major critical infrastructure assets.

And I ask that here because it seems like there is a very wide degree of those assets that are financed or operated in Italy by Chinese companies and in particularly in ports and in Trieste under the you new BRI memorandum that was signed -- bridges, roads and highways as well.

So it seems like a great deal of Italy's economic infrastructure is kind of moving in the direction of sort of Chinese influence and the I guess underlying point is those types of things tend to require the Chinese companies to work very closely with Italian government and financial institutions and get more deeply embedded in the way decisions are made and the way budget and resource --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ok. Thanks -- Chris.

BARTIROMO: We are watching the press conference in Rome. We just heard secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that one of the issues was that the Democrats contacted staffers directly in the State Department and told them don't hire your own legal counsel.

I just want to point out that that did not work out well for Carter Page. That's what they did to Carter Page in 2016. They told him, come in, we want to talk to you. Don't have any legal counsel. And then they wiretapped him.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: This goes back to what Andy McCarthy was talking about though. Again this is not a formal process. This is a show.

And it's a stunt by Congress to use this as a political weapon. We won't tolerate the bullying and intimidation of State Department employees. Congress is a co-equal branch of government and what they're doing violates the separation of powers, according to the secretary of state.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely right.

ANDY PUZDER, FORMER CKE RESTAURANT CEO: Who do these people think they are? The American people need to stand up to this and it needs to show up in the polling. What's going on here is ridiculous. It's horrific. It's anti-American.

This is -- I can't believe what's going on in Washington D.C. right now.

BARTIROMO: It's absolutely extraordinary. And we are talking this morning with Congressman Mark Green. Congressman, your reaction to what you're hearing here as well as you were in the middle of a thought on Don Peebles question of doesn't Congress have better things to do. You've got a lot of things hanging in the balance.

GREEN: Yes. I mean you look at the belt-and-road issue that they're talking about right now. I mean there are incredibly complex issues facing America and facing the world and China's belt and road agreement with Italy is very concerning. I'd love to dig into that.

But I'll give you another example. I have a bill that would save rural hospitals. It's a 35-mile exclusion and access -- critical access dollars and yet I can't get that bill heard. I even have a Democrat committee chairman who has signed on to co-sponsor the bill. I can't get that bill heard to help rural hospitals in America because the committees are all tied up investigating this president. And investigating with no authority from the House itself.

So the people of America have no voice. She has shut that down and basically initiated this process on her own as the Speaker of the House. It's unconscionable and as someone said earlier un-American.

PEEBLES: Congressman -- I think the Democrats though would argue that something similar, the obstruction approach was what was confronting Barack Obama. So when Barack Obama was president, and Republicans had control over Congress during his term, there was obstruction as well.

Is this the new way politics is done and we have lost the bipartisanship way of governing? Is this what we can see going forward? Or how do the American people get their government to work for them?

GREEN: You elect Republicans. That's how you do it because you look when we had control of the House, we passed tax reform that has blown this economy up. We passed in the House at least healthcare reform and sent it over to the Senate and there was a little hiccup over there but we did things when we had control of the House.

And that's what needs to happen. We need to take back control of the House. I mean, Leader McCarthy, as I was -- I think I was starting this thought when you jumped over to Mike's comments, you know, Leader McCarthy has tried multiple times to get a vote on this issue so that the people's voice can be heard in it.

Every time they table the motion and there's no vote taken. So it's not the way to do business in a democracy.

PUZDER: Mark -- this is Andy Puzder and by the way, being my congressman, I feel free to ask you these questions.

GREEN: Fire away -- Andy.

PUZDER: Impeachment's going to have to be bipartisan. They're going to need the support of some Republicans. The polling is showing that Republicans in the general public are very supportive of the President. Are you seeing any weakness in the Republican caucus on the Hill as far as support for the President in this process goes?

GREEN: No, I've seen -- I think our caucus is standing pretty firm together. And I will tell you that in the district, in my district, it's hugely supportive of the President and very, very angry about this process.

So both the caucus is standing together and I think at least in my district the folks who support me are 100 percent behind the president.

BARTIROMO: Do you think USMCA has any shot of coming to the floor? I mean is that one of the priorities? Are you going to vote for it if it does and do you expect it?

GREEN: Absolutely I'd vote for it. It's a great deal. Even liberal economists have said that the USMCA would produce 200,000 plus jobs in America.

I mean it is a fantastic agreement for farmers. It even helps union members, people that -- you know, typically Republicans, you know, have not reached out to, but I mean this is a fantastic, a fantastic opportunity and we have to get it passed. I'd absolutely support it.

Do I see it happening? No. I don't have a whole lot of hope that the Democrats are going to do anything but investigate the President. I told the President the other day, he needs to go find his lemonade stand permit from when he was 12 years old because they're coming after that too.

BARTIROMO: Wow. This is an extraordinary moment in time -- Congressman.

GREEN: It's unbelievable.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It is unbelievable and we'll see how the voters react. I mean it looks like the President's not having any trouble raising money but, you know, there's an election next year. We'll see how that plays out.

GREEN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- good to see you. Thank you.

GREEN: Thanks. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Mark Green joining us there.

We'll take a break.

When we come back we're talking about big tech, Mark Zuckerberg hitting back. The technology chief sounds off on competition and potential regulation. The legal battle for Facebook coming up.

Then the best states for your money, Florida attracting residents for sand, sun and tax relief. We're looking at the least taxed states in the country.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are focused on big tech now. Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg in the hot seat after the company meeting conversation leak. It revealed his hypothetical plan to push back against an Elizabeth Warren presidency over her proposal to break up big tech. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: Elizabeth Warren thinks that the right answer is to break up the company. I mean if she gets elected president and I would bet that we would have a legal challenge and I would bet that we will win the legal challenge. Does that still suck for us? Yes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Judge -- good to see you.

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: So what do you think about Facebook and regulation?

NAPOLITANO: Well, I think his fear is legitimate. I mean here's how it would work. A President Warren can't get legislation from the Congress to break up Facebook because the Fifth Amendment protects -- insulates them from that.

But she could direct her Department of Justice to commence an anti-trust investigation which would have to show, one, that Facebook monopolizes the market so that's pretty obvious and two, that this monopoly harms consumers.

Now, the product is delivered for free. So it's hard to find a way that the courts will conclude that it harms consumers. But this type of litigation, think of the Microsoft litigation, think of the AT&T litigation.

If Elizabeth Warren were elected president and were reelected, I think the case would survive both of her terms. That's how long these things take and that's how expensive they are.

The government's goal would be to break up Facebook as they broke up the Bell System into many competing entities. They would have to persuade a judge that that is best for consumers and it would take years to make that argument.

BARTIROMO: This is something that both sides agree on. You've got Elizabeth Warren and Ted Cruz basically both saying that they want to break up.

Business is shaking in their boots over the potential of Elizabeth Warren winning this. What do you think?

PEEBLES: Oh yes. Look, I think the Democratic support, the financial support of the Democratic Party are very concerned because they're business people and they're Wall Street business people by and large. And they are concerned about what would happen to their fundamental business.

I mean what this will become if she gets the nomination, which I don't believe she will is it will be socialism versus capitalism. And Trump can say, hey, you may not like me, you may not like my style, but if you want socialism, here's your person. And if you want to continue our great capitalistic democracy, I'm your only alternative.

BARTIROMO: Dagen -- it's policy over personality.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. I think that it's not just Facebook. we have the leaked audio of Mark Zuckerberg but many, if not all, major technology companies are worried about government regulation. If you were in a business that touches consumers in any way, shape or form and are a tech company, you're worried about much greater regulation. You're even worried about making acquisitions at this point because again you're going to have an FTC -- this is not just Elizabeth Warren. This is virtually any of these Democratic candidates who are running for the nomination and even President Trump, that you're worried about the FTC coming in and saying and looking at every acquisition you're potentially taking --

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: Well they even more powerful than they've ever be4en. I mean Google does -- you know, have market share of 90 percent in search.

NAPOLITANO: Right. So the statement that Mark Zuckerberg made tells me, that he has a legal team preparing for this already. Even though he's nowhere near any of the nomination. And I agree with you, our pic is going to get the nominee.

Well look at what the business roundtable just did the other day. Right -- I will not be able to come down to go. Guess what, profits are not our priority anymore. What?

PUZDER: I'll tell you the truth. I don't think they meant that. The things that they talked about advocating are the kinds of things that would attract millennial customers. I think they actually were, by coming out in favor of the social justice issues, they were actually trying to bring in that customer base which is in the best interest of their shareholders and actually is an exercise in capitalism.

BARTIROMO: Fine but are you telling me that (INAUDIBLE) and the communities that they operate in were not important before? I mean come on, give me a break. It's all PR.

PUZDER: That's exactly right, it's all Pr. They were just trying to attract that PR --

(CROSSTALKING)

PEEBLES: I disagree with that.

MCDOWELL: Lie to me. Lie to me and tell me I don't need to lose 20 pounds.

PEEBLES: I disagree. I believe business has a greater purpose than just making a profit for its shareholders.

BARTIROMO: It's true.

PEEBLES: Our democracy is one of the pillars is capitalism and in order for our country to work, it needs to include everybody in its economy. And if you look at how women entrepreneurs have been treated by this nation in terms of the access to capital, access to opportunity, you look at how minorities are being treated, yes corporate America needs to do a heck of a lot better.

And look JPMorgan -- Jamie Dimon is leading an effort to provide access to capital and opportunity for minorities. I mean, other banks ought to follow what they're doing.

BARTIROMO: He's done a great job.

PEEBLES: But this is a new demand. And in order for business to be able to have the American people support an agenda that's pro-business, they're going to have to prove that the system works for everybody. So I don't think -- it's obvious.

PUZDER: No, that's exactly how capitalism should work. There is a demand for this and businesses are responding to that demand which is in the best interest of their shareholders and will generate more business.

NAPOLITANO: You can't take your eyes off of profit or you won't have a job.

PEEBLES: No, you can't. But you can be -- by the way, it is more profitable to be inclusive.

NAPOLITANO: Of course.

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: My only point is, you've got to tell me that employees and the communities you operate are important? Really?

PUZDER: Yes, because --

BARTIROMO: I guess I made the assumption that you were considering that.

PUZDER: No but the boy no longer mattered. After Reagan fired the air traffic controller. This set the tone that employees don't really matter anymore. It's profits and it's economic reward.

MCDOWELL: But it was upside down with Facebook where Facebook is like kumbaya with all its employees and then with the actual users, they gave companies access to people's data to make money off of it and tried to hide the fact for years and years and years.

People were going on the live video service and murdering people. There was a man who murdered his infant child and Facebook's attitude was like we've got to figure out how to put a stop to it.

BARTIROMO: We're a platform. And it keeps happening

MCDOWELL: You're a classic. you don't do anything about it. You asked for Elizabeth Warren to walk in your front door and rip your company up because you didn't do a better job. You're getting what you got coming.

BARTIROMO: At a minimum, these companies risk getting rid of this immunity right that they cannot be sued because they're platform companies and not content creators. I'm not buying it.

NAPOLITANO: That's congressional. If she became president or whoever is president, Donald Trump could do this if the votes were in the congress, could enact legislation to do that.

MCDOWELL: Nancy Pelosi could but she won't because these are liberal -- these are big Democratic donors, these technology companies and they're too busy trying to take down and annul a president.

BARTIROMO: She's too busy with her --

NAPOLITANO: Just so eloquently summarize the resulted in $5 billion fine which was a drop in the bucket.

BARTIROMO: That sure was, for Facebook.

NAPOLITANO: Biggest fine in history from the FTC.

BARTIROMO: I suspect there might be more coming -- Judge. I suspect there might be more.

Great to see you. Thank you so much.

PEEBLES: but the big political point i9s Facebook, he's coming out against Elizabeth Warren. This is like a big deal politically. What does it mean for the rest of Silicon Valley, who are they going to support if she's nominated.

BARTIROMO: Such good point

All right. Quick break. Quit -- exactly.

Quick break joining Napolitano. We will see you soon. Fed in focus, next up. we're going to with the president of the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank, Thomas Barkin on the other side of this break. Stay with us. We're talking manufacturing in America.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. A lot going on this morning. Markets are down. Continuing the selloff yesterday.

Our top story this half an hour, the Federal Reserve, there are new concerns about the economy after that weak manufacturing data yesterday. President Trump slammed Fed Chair Jay Powell again.

Edward Lawrence is live this morning in Richmond, Virginia with the president of the Richmond Fed, Thomas Barkin. Over to you, Edward.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Maria, and this is -- I'm in a conference in Harrisonburg, West Virginia -- Harrisonburg, Virginia actually, it's the Investing in Rural America is the conference sponsored by the Richmond Federal Reserve. The president of the Richmond Federal Reserve is here, Tom Barkin.

Let's start right into this, the Fed chairman has said basically the economy is expanding, bringing in the edges of the labor force here. Are we seeing a resurgence in rural America?

THOMAS BARKIN, PRESIDENT, RICHMOND FEDERAL RESERVE: Well, we got involved in this because our district has a lot of small towns in it, mining towns, agricultural towns and manufacturing towns. And the numbers would suggest to you that employment to population in those towns is 10 to 12 points lower than it is in the bigger cities.

So, I don't think I'd say there's resurgence quite yet but we are finding a lot of very positive things happening across our district and we brought a lot of the practitioners to this things together for a couple days to share that.

LAWRENCE: And manufacturing has been in the news. President Trump has blamed the Federal Reserve for a slowdown in manufacturing. Any truth to that? I mean, the dollar is very strong. Are you seeing that with the labor force and rural America?

BARKIN: Well, Manufacturing data's been weak for some time. I think it's very much related to trade and trade related uncertainty.

LAWRENCE: Do you think that -- is manufacturing in a recession? The St. Louis Federal Reserve President Jim Bullard believes that.

BARKIN: I don't know how to define a recession on a particular industry basis. What I would say is the manufacturing performance seems to be down. The most recent numbers would be modestly contractionary.

LAWRENCE: How about for the economy? We're talking about the federal funds rate where it is, do you think the people in rural America, those folks are at the edges of the workforce coming in. Do they need a rate cut going forward in order to stimulate to keep this going?

BARKIN: What's interesting in most of these small towns is there are jobs available. But we're having trouble getting the people to the jobs. Sometimes that's education and it's matching. Sometimes that's transportation, infrastructure, sometimes that's broad band.

I think there are jobs out there but this issue of how do we connect people to jobs, that's something we're focused on.

LAWRENCE: And you don't see that as connected to the federal funds rate and lower rates (INAUDIBLE)?

BARKIN: I see it much more connected to education. I see it much more connected to the ability to get to a job, the ability to have child care, to help yourself out while you're travelling to a job. Those are the kinds of issues that we're talking about at this conference.

LAWRENCE: Going forward, the next couple FOMC meetings, you're in the room on the discussions there. Will we see a rate cut going forward, do you believe? Which way is the --

BARKIN: There's a lot of time between this and the other meetings. At least for me, my posture is very balanced. I'm looking at the data on the economy and I'm looking at the data on uncertainty.

We've taken out some insurance as you know in the next couple meetings. We'll see what happens with that insurance and what kind of impact it has and importantly, there's a lot of information that's going to come in between now and then.

LAWRENCE: The expansion keep going, do you see a recession in the future?

BARKIN: I'm very hopeful we'll see an expansion on the -- to continue on the positive side, consumer spending continues to be strong, people have jobs, that's a very positive thing. Inflation seems to be firming.

On the other side, business investment has been flat for most of the year and I think that has a lot to do with confidence and in particular business confidence and what they see as significant uncertainty in the political and the geopolitical environments. And they're having trouble deciding how to invest without that certainty.

LAWRENCE: How hard is it to navigate then with that uncertainty in terms of rate cuts and what the Fed does for their tools?

BARKIN: I think it is hard to navigate with uncertainty and there's different schools of thought about, you know, whether one should move faster so that you can get ahead of the uncertainty or as William Brainard once said, you know, the higher the uncertainty, the more of a caution.

LAWRENCE: Last question here, on inflation last week you said the uncertainty is and I want to quote you here, limiting firms' ability and willingness to raise prices. So do you see inflation artificially low then?

BARKIN: I think one of the challenges we have against our dual mandate is getting inflation up to our two percent target.

I do believe as I talked to businesses, one of the big challenges they have is the confidence that they can pass on costs and price increases and they've been conditioned over many years, expectations are very anchored. But it's also the case whether it's the transparency on the internet, big box retailers and the power of the purchasing departments that they're very nervous about their ability to pass on prices.

When uncertainty is high -- human nature does suggest that we have a little bit more caution and pushing through a bigger price increase.

LAWRENCE: Tom Barkin, I appreciate your time for this.

Maria, you heard there, no recession coming up in the future there and -- from the Richmond Federal Reserve, they're looking at investing in rural America and the rural towns may benefit going forward. We'll see. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll be watching that. Great interview, Edward. Thank you Edward Lawrence and Thomas Barkin. We thank you sir.

Coming up, money saving moves, where to go if you want the biggest bang for your buck. We've got the list of the best states for taxes.

Then, on the payroll, WNBA Commissioner Cathy Engelbert is here. She's weighing in on the new California law, allowing college athletes to make some money. Stay with us, a lot to come.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are focused on state taxes now. Personal finance site Kiplinger out with the list of the best and worst tax states in America. Jackie DeAngelis is all over it. Good morning, Jackie.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT: Good morning to you. And it certainly pays to live in certain states according to this study.

So first let me explain how they did it, they took a hypothetical married couple that makes -- that lives in a $400,000 home and they crunched the numbers in each state. They didn't just look at income tax but they also looked at sales tax. They looked at gas tax. Syntaxes, alcohol, tobacco, etcetera.

And here is what they found. We'll start with the friendliest states first. Wyoming, Nevada, Tennessee, Florida, Alaska the top five in that order. Washington, South Dakota, North Dakota, Arizona, New Hampshire. Very interesting here, that's six of the seven states are states that don't have income tax.

Texas is the only one that didn't actually make this list in terms of the tax friendly. But also when I looked at Tennessee, North Dakota, Arizona, New Hampshire, very low state income taxes on a relative basis. Actually, New Hampshire only taxes interest and dividend income which I thought was interesting.

Let's look at the flip side in terms of the least tax friendly states. Illinois topped the list there. Connecticut, New York, as we were talking about in the break. You can imagine Wisconsin, New Jersey on that list as well.

Very interesting about New York, one of the highest for income tax. One of the highest for sales tax. Then you have the city tax, if you live in New York City. And housing prices are also falling here according to recent reports. That's because the mansion tax, then the transfer tax and you lost your SALT deduction. So, you know, it's interesting to see how many people are moving out of the state.

Don, to your point as we were talking, there's a Bloomberg article that says 277 people per day are leaving New York. And that's nearly double from a year ago.

So what I think is interesting about this conversation is people certainly think about their wallet when they're thinking about where they live. Even if their policies may be a little bit more liberal and I think when it comes to 2020, that may be something certainly that drives votes. We saw it last time and as long as the economy stays strong, that's how people are thinking right now.

BARTIROMO: You know, I wouldn't even mind paying that whole litany of taxes, which I do anyway.

DEANGELIS: You do.

BARTIROMO: If in fact -- if in fact things were going well in New York. There was a robbery outside the building last week. The crime is picking up. What do you think, Don?

DON PEEBLES, FOUNDER, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, PEEBLES CORPORATION: Well, I think New York is indicative of some of the other cities that are struggling right now. New York is run poorly. There's no way to get around it. It's got --

BARTIROMO: So it is about policy?

PEEBLES: Oh, I think it's definitely about policy and SALT didn't help New York. But New York is taxing fewer and fewer people because they're leaving. So the tax base is shrinking. They are raising taxes that perpetuates this exodus out of the city.

But quality of life, just like what you just said, you'd pay more and be willing to pay this if you had a good quality of life. The biggest challenge in New York is quality of life.

You look at the cities that -- and the states that we were just discussing, Wyoming, a great quality of life. Nevada, great quality of life. Florida, great quality of life. Tennessee, great quality of life.

So people are saying we're going to -- so you can go to these states, they have no state income tax and a good quality of life versus the highest tax state in the country overall for the top one percent, top 10 percent is New York and what are you getting for your money? You can't use the public school system either.

BARTIROMO: And you moved to Tennessee, right?

ANDY PUZDER, FORMER CEO, CKE RESTAURANTS: I did, and Don and I were talking earlier, a part of this -- a big part of this is who's leaving the state, it's not just that people are leaving; it's the tax base that's leaving. It's people that pay the most in taxes who are leaving the state to go other places.

(INAUDIBLE) that's what happened in California. California has I think 144 people that pay a huge percentage of tax in the state, those people if they're able to do so are leaving. Same thing's happening in New York. You have taxpayers leaving.

So, why -- you know, in California, why would you pay 13.3 percent in income tax plus 37 percent in federal tax, just that. That's over 50 percent slightly, right?

BARTIROMO: That's not even real estate.

PUZDER: Yes, that's -- it's not gas tax, it's not syntax. You go to Tennessee, you pay 37 percent. And Nashville is a wonderful -- I can tell you, Nashville is a wonderful place to live. So it's a real problem for these high tax states. They need to either cut their taxes or cut their spending.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: You know what you're doing though, you're inviting all these rich blue liberals into these low tax states and what they do is they move and then vote in people like, well, de Blasio, that changes the economic makeup of these towns and states.

PEEBLES: They don't vote for -- I can tell you that the description of voters you're talking about did not vote for de Blasio. They either didn't vote or they voted for someone else.

BARTIROMO: Are they turning Texas blue -- are they turning Texas blue? Are they turning it purple? That's what she's talking about.

PUZDER: I go to the drycleaners or the drugstore and I have people -- you know, people ask where you're from, I'll say California. They say, well, you're not going to vote Democrat now that you're here, are you?

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: But look at Andrew Gillum in Florida, he was a contender and running against Ron DeSantis for the governor of that state.

BARTIROMO: And he got close -- he got close.

MCDOWELL: He got close. Now, (INAUDIBLE) he was in favor for Medicare for All which rips up Medicare as we know. Which I still argue is one of the reasons that he didn't win because older Americans get wind of that and they say no way, no how and they won't vote for you.

But again, these -- when these people leave New York City, they take with them their liberal political ideas and their votes and you mark my words.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's not just individuals though, right, Jackie? You had General Electric leave Connecticut, remember that? I mean, you had the big hedge fund managers leave as well, New York.

DEANGELIS: Absolutely. If you can move a corporation, if you're an employee that is using technology and you are not chained to your location, who wouldn't want a better quality of life and to keep more of what they are earning.

I have friends that just on an anecdotal basis who constantly are moving down to Florida because they don't have to pay the income tax and it's beautiful. The weather is nicer and they're happier.

MCDOWELL: The shame for the people who live in here in New York City are the residents who can't move and they are forced to wade through what is essentially an open sewer. Their lives -- they are not as safe as they were. There is excrement all over the streets. Small businesses, big businesses are being -- there are theft going on every day. People are shop lifting. They're not being arrested. And it's not going to get any worse until something changes.

PEEBLES: Yes, the pendulum will change. New York's the great -- one of the greatest cities on the planet and its resilient and New Yorkers will get engaged. They're busy. They've been focusing on other things and some people have just said we've had it, we're leaving.

But they're going to -- as things get worse, New Yorkers are not going to tolerate it. They'll change leadership. They'll change approach to governing and then you'll see what -- you know, you'll see a change. But New York tends to have this pendulum that swings to one extreme and then you get a Giuliani and then kind of calming down with a Bloomberg who we had for 12 years. Then pendulum going --

PUZDER: So are we there yet?

BARTIROMO: Well, by the way, that's why they took away the SALT deduction because they want to force policy to change, because they were hiding it behind these -- you know, they were hiding the high taxes behind the deduction. I know it hurt, it hurt all of us.

MCDOWELL: Well, one other thing, a lot of these cities across the country, the smaller and mid-size cities, they are not prepared for the influx of residents. We were talking about this.

PEEBLES: That's true.

MCDOWELL: The infrastructure, just the roads in a place like the Research Triangle area of Raleigh, Durham, Chapel Hill, even Charlotte, North Carolina, they do not have the capacity to handle the number of people who are flooding into these areas.

So in terms of the pendulum swinging back, you get more pro-business policies here. You clean up the streets. You clean up the crime in New York and you'll have a reverse migration of people from these smaller cities back here.

PEEBLES: No, I don't think you're going to have a reverse migration. I think you'll see New York stabilize at a -- at a different level and a different place. Technology is liberated, companies and individuals to work pretty much anywhere in the planet.

And so, we're going to -- there -- these other states and these other cities are going to compete for businesses and employees and it's going to be driven by quality of life and business policies.

Amazon, their second headquarters is in Crystal City, Virginia where the individual tax rate is only 5-1/2 percent.

MCDOWELL: But worst traffic in the nation, hands down. Because I had to drive right by there going to my parents' house.

PEEBLES: And they're opening in Nashville.

BARTIROMO: We're going to -- we're going to be talking to one individual who actually is enjoying Florida as well, Ken Langone is in the studio today. He's in New York and in Florida. We're going to talk all about that.

Jackie, great reporting. Thank you so much.

Quick break and then college stars in focus, WNBA Commissioner, former Deloitte CEO, Cathy Engelbert is here on the debate over paying university athletes, that's next. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A new California law making it OK for college athletes to earn money from endorsements. The controversial legislation could have monumental effects on the future of university sports.

Joining us right now is the commissioner of the WNBA, Cathy Engelbert. And Cathy, it's great to see you. Thanks for being here.

CATHY ENGELBERT, COMMISSIONER, WNBA: Great to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on the move as actually a former college athlete, right, yourself?

ENGELBERT: Yes, you know, having played, obviously this is a complex issue, much more complex that's probably being reported. I think for the WNBA players and the NBA players they're speaking out. We welcome that. We're going to monitor its impact on our league and I think I can as a former college athlete, I think the jury is still out on whether this is the right move.

BARTIROMO: But what's the downside? Tell us about the downside of this.

ENGELBERT: Well, again, you know, people follow college athletics. In big part, you think about big college football programs, big college basketball programs on both the men's and women's side. And you think of the fan base for that, and they're following it because they're not paid athletes. And it isn't diluted by all the endorsements and things like that.

So I think it's about a fan base, especially a student fan base, which many of these colleges especially at the smaller D-1 where I played. So I do think there's -- it's complex and it's complex from an economic perspective around how you sell your image on in social and things like that.

PEEBLES: But isn't it -- isn't it a little bit out of balance, though when you look at the amount of money that college athletics is generating for these universities? The trade used to be you play basketball as a student athlete or you play with some other sport in college and you get a degree for free, so that was a trade-off.

And -- but college athletics is a very big business to many schools, especially many D-1 schools and so the athletes to be struggling and panhandling essentially to survive is unfair as well.

And so that's why you've had some of these suspensions and so forth, it's correct that they're struggling for money, so.

ENGELBERT: That's why I said it's a complex issue where economics comes into it for the school, for the player, and again, I think the fan base as well, but it's complicated.

PEEBLES: Yes, but it's free labor. I mean, you think about it, the players are being -- they're playing, they're generating millions of dollars for the university and they're getting nothing. And no -- most of them leave there without a degree because the schools have used them as a economic resource, as opposed to keeping their end of the bargain by educating them. And I think that because they want to keep them eligible so they can generate more money for the schools.

ENGELBERT: Right, the good news is for the WNBA and the women athletes, 95 percent are college graduates and do get their degree but I get you -- I get your point.

MCDOWELL: But the players in the WNBA need to get paid more. They need to figure out a way to make sure that they're compensated so these young women don't have to play overseas in the off season which puts a great strain on their bodies that comes straight from a friend of mine.

ENGELBERT: Great point, we're in active Collective Bargaining negotiations as we speak. And so that's been something coming from a three decade career over in the business world that's been great to come over and look at. We all have the same goals around Collective Bargaining, that's to work on the player experience, to bring more fans into the game and work on the economic model for the league. So that's what I'm working on now.

BARTIROMO: And of course, you've got those negotiations ongoing right now.

ENGELBERT: Yes, that's right.

BARTIROMO: Cathy, it's good to have you. Thank you so much.

ENGELBERT: Great to be here, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Cathy Engelbert joining us right now. Back in a minute.

Sep 09, 2019( The Today File: https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/ Delivered by Newstex) SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — A group of states led by Texas is expected to announce an investigation into Google on Monday to examine whether the Silicon Valley tech giant has gotten too big and effective at stomping or acquiring rivals.The probe is the latest blow against big tech companies as antitrust investigations ramp up in the U.S. and around the world. A separate group of states announced an investigation into Facebook's dominance on Friday. The Department of Justice , the Federal Trade Commission and Congress are also conducting probes.Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton has said only that the investigation will look at 'whether large tech companies have engaged in anticompetitive behavior that stifled competition, restricted access, and harmed consumers.'

Reports in The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal say Google will be the primary target.Google expects state attorneys general will ask it about past similar investigations in the U.S. and internationally, senior vice president of global affairs Kent Walker wrote in a blog post Friday .Google's parent company, Alphabet, has a market value of more than $820 billion and controls so many aspects of the internet that it's hard to imagine surfing the web for long without running into at least one of its services. Experts believe the antitrust probe could focus on at least one of three aspects of Google's business that have caught regulators' eyes.An obvious first place to look could be online advertising. Google will control 31.1% of global digital ad dollars in 2019, according to eMarketer estimates, crushing a distant second place Facebook. And many smaller advertisers have argued that Google has such a stranglehold on the market that it becomes a system of whatever Google says, goes — because the alternative could be not reaching customers.Advertising'There's definitely concern on the part of the advertisers themselves that Google wields way too much power in setting rates and favoring their own services over others,' said Jen King, the director of privacy at Stanford's Center for Internet and Society.Critics often point to Google's 2007 acquisition of online advertising company DoubleClick as pivotal to its advertising dominance.Europe's antitrust regulators slapped Google with a $1.7 billion fine in March unfairly inserting exclusivity clauses into contracts with advertisers, disadvantaging rivals in the online advertising business.Another visibly huge piece of Google's business is its search platform, often the starting point for millions of people when they go online. Google dwarfs other search competitors and has faced harsh criticism in the past for favoring its own products over competitors at the top of search results. European regulators have also investigated here — ultimately fining Google for promoting its own shopping service. Google is appealing the fine.Google has long argued that although its businesses are large, they are useful and beneficial to consumers. But it appears regulators are growing more concerned not just with the effects on regular internet users, but on smaller companies as well.'On the one hand, you could just say, 'well Google is dominant because they're good,'' King said. 'But at the same time, it's created an ecosystem where people's whole internet experience is mediated through Google's home page and Google's other products.'AdvertisingOne outcome antitrust regulators might explore is forcing Google to spin off search as a separate company, she said.Then there's Google's smartphone operating system, Android. Another acquisition of Google's, the system is the most widely used in the world.European regulators have also fined Google to the tune of $5 billion for tactics involving Android, finding that Google forced handset makers to install Google apps, thereby increasing its reach. Google has since allowed more options for alternative browser and search apps to European Android phones. It's also possible U.S. states won't follow in Europe's footsteps. They could, for instance, focus on areas such as Google's popular video site YouTube, yet another acquisition Google made, that time in 2006.Google executive Walker emphasized that the company's products help people every day.'Google is one of America's top spenders on research and development, making investments that spur innovation: Things that were science fiction a few years ago are now free for everyone_translating any language instantaneously, learning about objects by pointing your phone, getting an answer to pretty much any question you might have,' he wrote. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X16-B121-JBCN-40XM-00000-00States expected to target Google in new antitrust probe2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:53ZLexisNexisNATIONALStates expected to target Google in new antitrust probeRachel Lerman

SAN FRANCISCO -- A group of states led by Texas is expected to announce an investigation into Google on Monday to examine whether the Silicon Valley tech giant has gotten too big and effective at stomping or acquiring rivals.

The probe is the latest blow against big tech companies as antitrust investigations ramp up in the U.S. and around the world. A separate group of states announced an investigation into Facebook's dominance on Friday. The Department of Justice, the Federal Trade Commission and Congress are also conducting probes.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton has said only that the investigation will look at "whether large tech companies have engaged in anticompetitive behavior that stifled competition, restricted access, and harmed consumers." Reports in The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal say Google will be the primary target.

Google expects state attorneys general will ask it about past similar investigations in the U.S. and internationally, senior vice president of global affairs Kent Walker wrote in a blog post Friday .

Google's parent company, Alphabet, has a market value of more than $820 billion and controls so many aspects of the internet that it's hard to imagine surfing the web for long without running into at least one of its services. Experts believe the antitrust probe could focus on at least one of three aspects of Google's business that have caught regulators' eyes.

An obvious first place to look could be online advertising. Google will control 31.1 percent of global digital ad dollars in 2019, according to eMarketer estimates, crushing a distant second place Facebook. And many smaller advertisers have argued that Google has such a stranglehold on the market that it becomes a system of whatever Google says, goes -- because the alternative could be not reaching customers.

"There's definitely concern on the part of the advertisers themselves that Google wields way too much power in setting rates and favoring their own services over others," said Jen King, the director of privacy at Stanford's Center for Internet and Society.

Critics often point to Google's 2007 acquisition of online advertising company DoubleClick as pivotal to its advertising dominance.

Europe's antitrust regulators slapped Google with a $1.7 billion fine in March unfairly inserting exclusivity clauses into contracts with advertisers, disadvantaging rivals in the online advertising business.

Another visibly huge piece of Google's business is its search platform, often the starting point for millions of people when they go online. Google dwarfs other search competitors and has faced harsh criticism in the past for favoring its own products over competitors at the top of search results. European regulators have also investigated here -- ultimately fining Google for promoting its own shopping service. Google is appealing the fine.

Google has long argued that although its businesses are large, they are useful and beneficial to consumers. But it appears regulators are growing more concerned not just with the effects on regular internet users, but on smaller companies as well.

"On the one hand, you could just say, 'well Google is dominant because they're good,'" King said. "But at the same time, it's created an ecosystem where people's whole internet experience is mediated through Google's home page and Google's other products."

One outcome antitrust regulators might explore is forcing Google to spin off search as a separate company, she said.

Then there's Google's smartphone operating system, Android. Another acquisition of Google's, the system is the most widely used in the world.

European regulators have also fined Google to the tune of $5 billion for tactics involving Android, finding that Google forced handset makers to install Google apps, thereby increasing its reach. Google has since allowed more options for alternative browser and search apps to European Android phones.

It's also possible U.S. states won't follow in Europe's footsteps. They could, for instance, focus on areas such as Google's popular video site YouTube, yet another acquisition Google made, that time in 2006.

Google executive Walker emphasized that the company's products help people every day.

"Google is one of America's top spenders on research and development, making investments that spur innovation: Things that were science fiction a few years ago are now free for everyone_translating any language instantaneously, learning about objects by pointing your phone, getting an answer to pretty much any question you might have," he wrote.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X16-57S1-JBCN-428Y-00000-00States eye Google in antitrust probe2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:53ZLexisNexisBUSINESSStates eye Google in antitrust probeRACHEL LERMANTHE HERALD-DISPATCH

WASHINGTON - Fifty U.S. states and territories, led by Texas, announced an investigation into Google's "potential monopolistic behavior."

The Monday announcement closely followed one from a separate group of states Friday that disclosed an investigation into Facebook's market dominance. The two probes widen the antitrust scrutiny of big tech companies beyond sweeping federal and congressional investigations and enforcement action by European regulators.

Nebraska attorney general Doug Peterson, a Republican, said at a press conference held in Washington that 50 attorneys general joining together sends a "strong message to Google."

California and Alabama are not part of the investigation, although it does include the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Google is headquartered in California and employs more workers there than in any other region. Google also broke ground last year on a $600 million data-center project in Alabama.

Tara Gallegos, a spokeswoman for California Attorney General Xavier Becerra, declined to confirm or deny any state investigation and would not comment on the announcement by the other states. Mike Lewis, a spokesman for Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall, also said the state's legal team had no comment on the probe.

The news conference featured a dozen Republican attorneys general plus the Democratic attorney general of Washington, D.C.

Google's parent company, Alphabet, has a market value of more than $820 billion and controls so many facets of the internet that it's almost impossible to surf the web for long without running into at least one of its services. Google's dominance in online search and advertising enables it to target millions of consumers for their personal data.

The state officials assembled in Washington were vague about the focus and scope of the investigation, although several suggested scrutiny of the company's dominant search and advertising businesses.

Critics often point to Google's 2007 acquisition of online advertising company DoubleClick as pivotal to its advertising dominance.

Europe's antitrust regulators slapped Google with a $1.7 billion fine in March for unfairly inserting exclusivity clauses into contracts with advertisers, disadvantaging rivals in the online ad business.

One outcome antitrust regulators might explore is forcing Google to spin off search as a separate company, experts say. Regulators also could focus on areas such as Google's popular video site YouTube, an acquisition Google scored in 2006.

Google has long argued that although its businesses are large, they are useful and beneficial to consumers.

"Google is one of America's top spenders on research and development, making investments that spur innovation," wrote Kent Walker, the company's senior vice president of global affairs, in a blog post Friday . On Monday, Google referred reporters to that earlier post.

"Things that were science fiction a few years ago are now free for everyone - translating any language instantaneously, learning about objects by pointing your phone, getting an answer to pretty much any question you might have," Walker wrote.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5BXK-DWV1-JCMN-Y21C-00000-00States Getting in on Patent Infringement Fight2014-04-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:53ZLexisNexisStates Getting in on Patent Infringement Fight

Apr 07, 2014 (Patent Law Community: Delivered by Newstex)
by Rich Ehisen
For all intents and purposes, patent law reform is an issue that has long been the purview of the federal government and the court system. But with intense pressure building at all levels of government to combat so-called "patent trolls" — companies that exist primarily to sue other companies over often-questionable patent infringement claims — a growing number of states are now jumping into the fray. Officially known by the less pejorative terms "patent assertion entities" (PAEs) or "non-practicing entities" (NPEs), these companies rarely manufacture or create any real products of their own.

Rather, as the Federal Trade Commission notes, they are "firms with a business model based primarily on purchasing patents and then attempting to generate revenue by asserting the intellectual property against persons who are already practicing the patented technologies." In other words, PAEs buy patents, often on the cheap, and then threaten to sue companies that may be using technology covered by those patents unless that businesses fork over significant amounts of money. The key word here is "may." Critics contend that too often the patent claim doesn't actually apply to the technology in question or the patent is too vague to even know if it does. But the cost of proving that in court can be prohibitive — into the millions of dollars in many cases. In fact, the more money is on the line the higher the legal fees can be for the company defending itself. And because most patent infringement attorneys work on a contingency fee basis, the patent holder has minimal or no upfront costs. Sufficiently lodged between a rock and a hard place, many companies threatened with such litigation simply roll over and write a check for the amount the PAE is asking for...which conveniently is often just a bit less than the cost of taking the case to court. Although tech giants like Google, ATT, Verizon and Apple remain the top targets for such infringement claims, small businesses are fast getting into the crosshairs as well. A 2012 Boston University study showed that "small and medium-sized entities made up 90 percent of the companies sued, accounting for 59 percent of the defenses, and paid about 37 percent of the aggregate costs in 2011." Some of those came for acts as mundane as using ubiquitous technology like WiFi. One Texas-based PAE called MPHJ Technologies, which in 2012 purchased a series of patents for the total price of $1, has sent threatening letters to over 16,000 small businesses nationwide that have copying machines with the capability of scanning a document and sending it to someone via email with a single push of a button. Those letters demand the companies pay between $1,000 and $1,200 per employee to "license" the machines for use or face a lawsuit. None of the companies receiving the letter actually built the scanners in question, but MPHJ claims that isn't the issue anyway; they say the infringement happens when users connect the machines to the Internet. That drew the threat of a deceptive practices lawsuit from the FTC. But MPHJ was anything but cowed; in January the company beat the agency to the punch, filing a suit against the FTC claiming it was illegally preventing it from enforcing its patent holdings. None of this has occurred in a vacuum. Congress passed a moderate reform measure in 2011, the America Invents Act, which created a "first to file" system that gives patent ownership to the person who filed their application first regardless of whether someone else later claims they invented the product beforehand. The first major Congressional patent reform in over half a century, it also allows vendors — for example the maker of the copying machine — to wade into the legal fight on behalf of their customers. President Barack Obama followed that in 2013 with five executive orders that, among several things, push the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office to tighten up requirements for issuing patents in the first place. The U.S. House of Representatives took action as well, passing HB 3309, the Innovation Act of 2013, last December. That measure would force patent infringement litigants to name the product they say is being infringed upon by its specific name and patent number. It also would require disclosure of the entity that actually owns the patents and stands to gain financially from the litigation (MPHJ, for instance, has over 101 subsidiaries it uses to conduct its activities) and impose a fee-shifting element that would force a failed litigant to pay the winner's legal fees. A handful of bills are also pending in the U.S. Senate, though how closely whatever passes there will resemble the House version — which President Obama favors — remains to be seen. All this would naturally lead one to presume that anyone pursuing a patent infringement suit is a patent troll and that such suits have become epidemic. Neither assertion, however, is entirely correct. Many reform advocates again cite the Boston University study, which also claims that PAE suits make up about two thirds of all patent infringement cases. But that figure encompasses just suits filed by patent holders that aren't also a manufacturers of products, including universities, individual inventors and other research facilities. A 2013 report from the U.S. Government Accountability Office that excludes those entities places the figure at less than 20 percent of all those filed from 2007 to 2011. "There is a large debate right now over exactly how big of a problem this actually is," says Peter Lee, a law professor at the University of California, Davis who specializes in patent law. "It really depends on the definition we use. Are universities patent trolls? And what about large incumbent technology companies? They produce products, but many also have enormous patent portfolios that they use in a leveraged manner." "I would be skeptical of taking any particular figure at face value," he adds. Even so, states are now getting into the game as well. Last year, Vermont became the first state to pass legislation (HB 299 2013) that bars so-called "bad faith" infringement suits or threats. The law gives judges a variety of conditions and factors designed to help them determine what does and does not constitute a bad faith suit. The law also allows the infringement target to countersue someone found to be suing in bad faith and authorizes the attorney general to bring civil actions against that individual as well. Several states have followed suit this year, including Idaho, Oregon, and South Dakota. At least five more — Georgia, Virginia, Utah, Wisconsin and Alabama — have sent bills to the governor, with Maryland expected to do so any day now. Bills are still pending in at least 14 states, including Kentucky, Missouri and Hew Hampshire, where they have all cleared at least one chamber. "This is an indication of how broadly the pro-reform lobby is pushing its agenda," says Russ Merbeth, Chief Policy Counsel for Intellectual Ventures, Inc., a PAE that is often cited as a patent troll by reform advocates. "There are a lot of big tech companies that have found it to be much more cost effective to take their liability issues to Congress or state legislatures to deal with than to deal with them in the marketplace." http://www.lexisnexis.com/legalnewsroom/cfs-file.ashx/__key/communityserver-blogs-components-weblogfiles/00-00-00-00-32/0028.2014-04_2D00_07-StateNet.jpg
Merbeth also insists that without companies like his, many individual inventors and small businesses would not have the means to enforce valid patents they legally hold when a larger company infringes on those patents. He says most PAEs are fine with new rules that rid the playing field "of the bad actors out there," but called the current Congressional bills "omnibus, blunderbuss" proposals that would do more harm than good. How much state actions impact what happens in Congress remains to be seen. Law professor Lee says questions still remain over how much authority states have to police bad faith infringement cases, but he believes they will play a big role in whatever reforms eventually do come out of Congress. "This action at the state level could definitely spark more federal action," he says, noting that it also wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing if PAEs had to deal with varying state laws. "Not being certain of how bad faith is defined state to state could have a chilling effect on those that operate like trolls," he says. The United States Supreme Court is also a major player, having already heard oral arguments in multiple patent cases this year. One of those, Alice v. CLS, came just last Monday and seeks to define just how broadly a software application can be applied. Alice Corp., an Australian-owned company, claims CLS Bank illegally used Alice-patented software in some of its computer programming. CLS counters that the program in question is ubiquitous and not worthy of specific patent protection. The High Court's rulings are due in June. Some reformers believe a ruling in favor of CLS Bank would be a severe blow to PAEs, though nothing resembling a fatal one. And regardless of whatever reforms the states, the courts and Congress devise, they won't solve what Lee says is the underlying issue: too many patents already in the system. "About 40 percent of all the patents challenged in litigation should never have been granted in the first place," he says. "Even if we reduce now the number being issued, there are still tons out there that will be around for decades. So we're not really close to the end on this issue at all."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X0J-D5D1-DY37-F290-00000-00States hit Facebook and Google with new probes2019-09-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:53ZLexisNexisBUSINESSAPg. 13States hit Facebook and Google with new probesMarcy Gordon and Matt O'BrienAssociated Press

Facebook is one of the world's largest and most ubiquitous tech companies.Noah Berger/AP

WASHINGTON - Two groups of states are targeting Facebook and Google in separate antitrust probes, widening the scrutiny of Big Tech beyond sweeping federal and congressional investigations into their market dominance.

Facebook and Google are two of the world's largest and most ubiquitous tech companies.

The billions who use their services for making social media posts, uploading videos or searching ads are targeted by the tech companies for their personal data - a prized asset that enhances the companies' power.

Regulators are examining whether the companies have used their market power to crimp competition, potentially raising prices and hurting consumers.

New York Attorney General Letitia James, a Democrat, confirmed the Facebook investigation in a news release Friday, saying the probe by the coalition of states she is leading would focus on Facebook's "dominance in the industry and the potential anticompetitive conduct stemming from that dominance."

A separate group of state attorneys general is announcing Monday in Washington the launch of an investigation into "whether large tech companies have engaged in anticompetitive behavior that stifled competition, restricted access and harmed consumers," an advisory from Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton said Friday.

The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal, citing sources they didn't identify, have reported that target will be Google.

Both groups of state attorneys general include Democrats and Republicans.

With some 2.4 billion users around the globe and a huge social media presence, Facebook has sparked outrage with a series of privacy scandals and its use by Russian operatives in the 2016 presidential campaign.

In July, Facebook was hit with a $5 billion fine from the Federal Trade Commission over privacy violations.

"Even the largest social media platform in the world must follow the law and respect consumers," James said.

She said the probe would seek to determine if Facebook endangered consumer data, reduced the quality of consumer choices or increased the price of advertising.

The U.S. Justice Department opened a sweeping antitrust investigation of big tech companies this summer, looking at whether their online platforms have hurt competition, suppressed innovation or otherwise harmed consumers.

The Federal Trade Commission has been conducting its own competition probe of Big Tech, as has the House Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust.

The lawmaker leading that investigation, Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., said Friday the states' probe of Facebook is "completely appropriate."

"Facebook has proven time and time again that it cannot be trusted to regulate itself," Cicilline said.

urn:contentItem:5X0J-D5D1-DY37-F1TD-00000-00States hit Facebook and Google with new probes2019-09-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:53ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBPg. 5States hit Facebook and Google with new probesMarcy Gordon; and Matt O'BrienAssociated Press

WASHINGTON - Two groups of states are targeting Facebook and Google in separate antitrust probes, widening the scrutiny of Big Tech beyond sweeping federal and congressional investigations into their market dominance.

Facebook and Google are two of the world's largest and most ubiquitous tech companies

The billions who use their services for making social media posts, uploading videos or searching ads are targeted by the tech companies for their personal data - a prized asset that enhances the companies' power.

Regulators are examining whether the companies have used their market power to crimp competition, potentially raising prices and hurting consumers.

New York Attorney General Letitia James, a Democrat, confirmed the Facebook investigation in a news release Friday, saying the probe by the coalition of states she is leading would focus on Facebook's "dominance in the industry and the potential anticompetitive conduct stemming from that dominance."

A separate group of state attorneys general is announcing Monday in Washington the launch of an investigation into "whether large tech companies have engaged in anticompetitive behavior that stifled competition, restricted access and harmed consumers," an advisory from Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton said Friday.

The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal, citing sources they didn't identify, have reported that target will be Google.

Both groups of state attorneys general include Democrats and Republicans.

With some 2.4 billion users around the globe and a huge social media presence, Facebook has sparked outrage with a series of privacy scandals and its use by Russian operatives in the 2016 presidential campaign.

In July, Facebook was hit with a $5 billion fine from the Federal Trade Commission over privacy violations.
